Psychology_tweet_144.News Finding: New #ReadiLab piece online describing enhanced pleasure from smoking cigs while drinking but not while smoking pot
Psychology_tweet_144.Paper Finding: In contrast, there was on average no change in perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes when using marijuana (5.3 ± 2.7, t (199) ¼ 1.7, p ¼ .09).
Psychology_tweet_144.News Context: New #ReadiLab piece online describing enhanced pleasure from smoking cigs while drinking but not while smoking pot
Psychology_tweet_144.Paper Context: Individuals reported an increase in perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes when drinking alcohol (7.0 ± 2.2 versus null hypothesis 5 ¼ "no increase or decrease in pleasure"; t (199) ¼13.0, p < .001). In contrast, there was on average no change in perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes when using marijuana (5.3 ± 2.7, t (199) ¼ 1.7, p ¼ .09). Perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes did not differ by frequency of binge drinking (F (3,200) ¼ 0.84, p ¼ .47): nonbinge (7.1 ± 2.1), 1-3 binge days (6.8 ± 2.3), 4-8 binge days (7.0 ± 2.1), 9 þ binge days (7.6 ± 2.2).
Psychology_tweet_144.text:
['Finding A: New #ReadiLab piece online describing enhanced pleasure from smoking cigs while drinking but not while smoking pot
Finding B: In contrast, there was on average no change in perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes when using marijuana (5.3 ± 2.7, t (199) ¼ 1.7, p ¼ .09).']
Psychology_tweet_144.displayed_text:
Finding A: New #ReadiLab piece online describing enhanced pleasure from smoking cigs while drinking but not while smoking pot
Finding B: In contrast, there was on average no change in perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes when using marijuana (5.3 ± 2.7, t (199) ¼ 1.7, p ¼ .09).

Psychology_tweet_220.News Finding: Dog's gaze following tuned to human communicative signals:
Psychology_tweet_220.Paper Finding: Furthermore, dogs followed the actor's gaze significantly less in the BC compared to the O condition [cumulative accuracy, two-sample t test, t(24) = 22.107, p = 0.045].
Psychology_tweet_220.News Context: Dog's gaze following tuned to human communicative signals:
Psychology_tweet_220.Paper Context: Importantly, however, the accuracy indexes calculated for the cueing phase did not capture gaze following in BC [mean 6 SEM of cumulative accuracy: 20.06 6 0.14; one-sample t test, t(12) = 20.433; p = 0.67; first look: 0.11 6 0.16; one-sample t test, t(12) = 0.695; p = 0.5]. Furthermore, dogs followed the actor's gaze significantly less in the BC compared to the O condition [cumulative accuracy, two-sample t test, t(24) = 22.107, p = 0.045]. These data suggest that the lack of gaze following, when there are no ostensive signals, cannot be accounted for by the confounding effect of ''artificial'' salient attention getter used in the NO condition, also providing further support for the significant role of ostensive signals in dogs' gaze response.
Psychology_tweet_220.text:
['Finding A: Dog\'s gaze following tuned to human communicative signals:
Finding B: Furthermore, dogs followed the actor\'s gaze significantly less in the BC compared to the O condition [cumulative accuracy, two-sample t test, t(24) = 22.107, p = 0.045].']
Psychology_tweet_220.displayed_text:
Finding A: Dog's gaze following tuned to human communicative signals:
Finding B: Furthermore, dogs followed the actor's gaze significantly less in the BC compared to the O condition [cumulative accuracy, two-sample t test, t(24) = 22.107, p = 0.045].

Psychology_tweet_45.News Finding: Immune dysfunction in autism. Pathophysiological pathways.
Psychology_tweet_45.Paper Finding: Furthermore, these dysfunctional immune responses are associated with increased impairments in behaviors characteristic of core features of ASD, in particular, deficits in social interactions and communication.
Psychology_tweet_45.News Context: Immune dysfunction in autism. Pathophysiological pathways.
Psychology_tweet_45.Paper Context: Furthermore, these dysfunctional immune responses are associated with increased impairments in behaviors characteristic of core features of ASD, in particular, deficits in social interactions and communication. This review will discuss the current state of our knowledge of immune dysfunction in ASD, how these findings may impact on underlying neuro-immune mechanisms and implicate potential areas where the manipulation of the immune response could have an impact on behavior and immunity in ASD. There is a concordance rate for ASD of 0-37% reported for dizygotic twins, while concordance rates of 44-91% are reported for monozygotic twins (Bailey et al., 1995; Constantino and Todd, 2000; Kates et al., 2004; Steffenburg et al., 1989) , suggesting that genetic composition may contribute to increased risk of developing ASD.
Psychology_tweet_45.text:
['Finding A: Immune dysfunction in autism. Pathophysiological pathways.
Finding B: Furthermore, these dysfunctional immune responses are associated with increased impairments in behaviors characteristic of core features of ASD, in particular, deficits in social interactions and communication.']
Psychology_tweet_45.displayed_text:
Finding A: Immune dysfunction in autism. Pathophysiological pathways.
Finding B: Furthermore, these dysfunctional immune responses are associated with increased impairments in behaviors characteristic of core features of ASD, in particular, deficits in social interactions and communication.

Psychology_510.News Finding: Beckley, who is in the department of psychology and neuroscience at Duke, said the adult-onset group had a history of anti-social behavior back to childhood, but reported committing relatively fewer crimes.
Psychology_510.Paper Finding: Our results showed that most of the official adult-onset men began their antisocial activities during early childhood.
Psychology_510.News Context: Using this unusually rich source of data, the study was able to look at childhood history compared with adult behavior. Beckley, who is in the department of psychology and neuroscience at Duke, said the adult-onset group had a history of anti-social behavior back to childhood, but reported committing relatively fewer crimes. This group reported committing more crimes than folks who had never been convicted, but fewer crimes than people who had been in trouble as juveniles.
Psychology_510.Paper Context: Our results, along with past research (see, for example, , indicate that as a whole, apparent adult-onset offenders are responsible for a small minority of total crime. Our results showed that most of the official adult-onset men began their antisocial activities during early childhood. In fact, on average, official adult-onset men were similar to juvenile-onset men on multiple measures of child and adolescent antisocial behavior.
Psychology_510.text:
['Finding A: Beckley, who is in the department of psychology and neuroscience at Duke, said the adult-onset group had a history of anti-social behavior back to childhood, but reported committing relatively fewer crimes.
Finding B: Our results showed that most of the official adult-onset men began their antisocial activities during early childhood.']
Psychology_510.displayed_text:
Finding A: Beckley, who is in the department of psychology and neuroscience at Duke, said the adult-onset group had a history of anti-social behavior back to childhood, but reported committing relatively fewer crimes.
Finding B: Our results showed that most of the official adult-onset men began their antisocial activities during early childhood.

Psychology_21.News Finding: In total,19 percent of the young volunteers involved in the study reported that they had been physically abusive to a partner during a dating relationship and 68 percent of the volunteers reported to experiencing corporal punishment as children.
Psychology_21.Paper Finding: Results In all, 19% of participants (n = 134) reported physical dating violence perpetration and 68% reported experiencing corporal punishment as children (n = 498).
Psychology_21.News Context: Of the 758 young adults recruited for the study, 61 percent were female. In total,19 percent of the young volunteers involved in the study reported that they had been physically abusive to a partner during a dating relationship and 68 percent of the volunteers reported to experiencing corporal punishment as children. There was a positive relationship between corporal punishment and physical violence during a romantic relationship.
Psychology_21.Paper Context: Results In all, 19% of participants (n = 134) reported physical dating violence perpetration and 68% reported experiencing corporal punishment as children (n = 498). Analysis showed a significant positive association between corporal punishment and physical perpetration of dating violence (OR 1.30, 95% CI 1.07-1.59). Even after controlling for sex, ethnicity, age, parental education, and child physical abuse, childhood corporal punishment was associated significantly with physical dating violence perpetration (aOR 1.29, 95% CI 1.02-1.62).
Psychology_21.text:
['Finding A: In total,19 percent of the young volunteers involved in the study reported that they had been physically abusive to a partner during a dating relationship and 68 percent of the volunteers reported to experiencing corporal punishment as children.
Finding B: Results In all, 19% of participants (n = 134) reported physical dating violence perpetration and 68% reported experiencing corporal punishment as children (n = 498).']
Psychology_21.displayed_text:
Finding A: In total,19 percent of the young volunteers involved in the study reported that they had been physically abusive to a partner during a dating relationship and 68 percent of the volunteers reported to experiencing corporal punishment as children.
Finding B: Results In all, 19% of participants (n = 134) reported physical dating violence perpetration and 68% reported experiencing corporal punishment as children (n = 498).

Psychology_275.News Finding: For example, in one experiment, people felt more environmentally conscious after they received a behaviorally targeted ad for a "green" product.
Psychology_275.Paper Finding: The results of study 3 replicate previous results by showing that ads identified as behaviorally targeted can affect consumer self-perceptions and hence behavior.
Psychology_275.News Context: For example, in one experiment, people felt more environmentally conscious after they received a behaviorally targeted ad for a "green" product. "The power of a behaviorally targeted ad for a green product isn't just that it persuades you to buy the advertised product. It actually makes you feel more environmentally conscious and can change your behavior," said Rebecca Walker Reczek, co-author of the study and associate professor of marketing at The Ohio State University's Fisher College of Business.
Psychology_275.Paper Context: , and this effect was not present when the order of the mediators was reversed (b ¼ .0046, SE ¼ .02, 95% CI, À.0297 to .0607). The results of study 3 replicate previous results by showing that ads identified as behaviorally targeted can affect consumer self-perceptions and hence behavior. Specifically, consumers receiving a behaviorally targeted ad for an environmentally friendly "green" product viewed themselves as possessing stronger green consumption values.
Psychology_275.text:
['Finding A: For example, in one experiment, people felt more environmentally conscious after they received a behaviorally targeted ad for a "green" product.
Finding B: The results of study 3 replicate previous results by showing that ads identified as behaviorally targeted can affect consumer self-perceptions and hence behavior.']
Psychology_275.displayed_text:
Finding A: For example, in one experiment, people felt more environmentally conscious after they received a behaviorally targeted ad for a "green" product.
Finding B: The results of study 3 replicate previous results by showing that ads identified as behaviorally targeted can affect consumer self-perceptions and hence behavior.

Psychology_tweet_217.News Finding: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession?
Psychology_tweet_217.Paper Finding: Across three studies, well-educated graduates who entered the workforce during economic downturns were more satisfied with their current jobs than those who entered during more prosperous economic times.
Psychology_tweet_217.News Context: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession?
Psychology_tweet_217.Paper Context: Across three studies, well-educated graduates who entered the workforce during economic downturns were more satisfied with their current jobs than those who entered during more prosperous economic times. Study 1 showed that economic conditions at college graduation predicted later job satisfaction even after accounting for different industry and occupational choices. Study 2 replicated these results and found that recession-era graduates were more satisfied with their jobs both early and later in their careers and even when they earned less money.
Psychology_tweet_217.text:
['Finding A: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession?
Finding B: Across three studies, well-educated graduates who entered the workforce during economic downturns were more satisfied with their current jobs than those who entered during more prosperous economic times.']
Psychology_tweet_217.displayed_text:
Finding A: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession?
Finding B: Across three studies, well-educated graduates who entered the workforce during economic downturns were more satisfied with their current jobs than those who entered during more prosperous economic times.

Psychology_448.News Finding: They also found that while older bipolar disorder patients had significantly accelerated epigenetic aging compared to controls, no difference was found in younger patients.
Psychology_448.Paper Finding: This might be one of the reasons why we only detected significant differences in epigenetic aging in older subjects, especially considering the key role proposed for chronic stress and the high rates of unhealthy lifestyles seen in BD patients .
Psychology_448.News Context: "Controlling these factors is just as important as taking medications," Fries said. They also found that while older bipolar disorder patients had significantly accelerated epigenetic aging compared to controls, no difference was found in younger patients. "We believe a difference wasn't detected in younger patients because they haven't had as much exposure to stressful events," Fries said.
Psychology_448.Paper Context: In line with previous results , our current findings suggest that DNAm age might represent a better aging marker than the commonly used telomere length, particularly in older individuals. This might be one of the reasons why we only detected significant differences in epigenetic aging in older subjects, especially considering the key role proposed for chronic stress and the high rates of unhealthy lifestyles seen in BD patients . Our findings suggest that accelerated epigenetic aging in BD may be at least partially associated with an increase in mtDNA copy number.
Psychology_448.text:
['Finding A: They also found that while older bipolar disorder patients had significantly accelerated epigenetic aging compared to controls, no difference was found in younger patients.
Finding B: This might be one of the reasons why we only detected significant differences in epigenetic aging in older subjects, especially considering the key role proposed for chronic stress and the high rates of unhealthy lifestyles seen in BD patients .']
Psychology_448.displayed_text:
Finding A: They also found that while older bipolar disorder patients had significantly accelerated epigenetic aging compared to controls, no difference was found in younger patients.
Finding B: This might be one of the reasons why we only detected significant differences in epigenetic aging in older subjects, especially considering the key role proposed for chronic stress and the high rates of unhealthy lifestyles seen in BD patients .

Psychology_263.News Finding: The result was that all participants rated the four odours more positively when they were presented with positive labels than when presented with negative labels.
Psychology_263.Paper Finding: Although labels appear to also influence intensity ratings and reaction times, this seems to be a more complex relationship that could be modulated by additional factors such as odor valence, label fit, and possibly the edibility attributed to an odor or a label.
Psychology_263.News Context: When associated with a pleasant label, we enjoy the odour more than when it is presented with a negative label. The result was that all participants rated the four odours more positively when they were presented with positive labels than when presented with negative labels. Specifically, participants described the odours as pleasant and edible (even those associated with non-food items) when associated with positive labels.
Psychology_263.Paper Context: In summary, odor labels affect pleasantness ratings and edibility perception. Although labels appear to also influence intensity ratings and reaction times, this seems to be a more complex relationship that could be modulated by additional factors such as odor valence, label fit, and possibly the edibility attributed to an odor or a label. Odors with different valences impact our mood and wellbeing in different ways.
Psychology_263.text:
['Finding A: The result was that all participants rated the four odours more positively when they were presented with positive labels than when presented with negative labels.
Finding B: Although labels appear to also influence intensity ratings and reaction times, this seems to be a more complex relationship that could be modulated by additional factors such as odor valence, label fit, and possibly the edibility attributed to an odor or a label.']
Psychology_263.displayed_text:
Finding A: The result was that all participants rated the four odours more positively when they were presented with positive labels than when presented with negative labels.
Finding B: Although labels appear to also influence intensity ratings and reaction times, this seems to be a more complex relationship that could be modulated by additional factors such as odor valence, label fit, and possibly the edibility attributed to an odor or a label.

Psychology_tweet_91.News Context: Learning a lot about sleep from @username. Naps and sleep are very important for young children to enhance emotional memory. Even more reasons for a daytime siesta.

Psychology_124.News Finding: "Sociosexual orientation is a relatively stable tendency toward or away from casual sex, determined by a combination of heritable factors, sociocultural learning, and past experiences, and reflected in three key components: motivation for, attitudes toward, and past experience with casual sex," the authors write.
Psychology_124.Paper Finding: Sociosexuality significantly predicted casual sex engagement after controlling for demographics, OR ¼ 2.06 [1.70, 2.49], p < .001; the interaction with gender was not significant, OR ¼ 1.13 [0.93, 1.36].
Psychology_124.News Context: They lurk in our bar's backrooms, on our gym's racquetball courts, on cruises and in airplanes, and on every street in the city of Miami. "Sociosexual orientation is a relatively stable tendency toward or away from casual sex, determined by a combination of heritable factors, sociocultural learning, and past experiences, and reflected in three key components: motivation for, attitudes toward, and past experience with casual sex," the authors write. The authors argue that there would be no reason to believe that this effect wouldn't extend to casual sex.
Psychology_124.Paper Context: By the 9-month follow-up, two fifths (42%) reported at least one penetrative casual encounter over the academic year; percentages were similar in both sexes, w 2 (1) < 1. Sociosexuality significantly predicted casual sex engagement after controlling for demographics, OR ¼ 2.06 [1.70, 2.49], p < .001; the interaction with gender was not significant, OR ¼ 1.13 [0.93, 1.36]. Only 23% of those scoring below the median on sociosexuality engaged in casual sex compared to 62% of those scoring above the median, w 2 (1) ¼ 57.73, p < .001.
Psychology_124.text:
['Finding A: "Sociosexual orientation is a relatively stable tendency toward or away from casual sex, determined by a combination of heritable factors, sociocultural learning, and past experiences, and reflected in three key components: motivation for, attitudes toward, and past experience with casual sex," the authors write.
Finding B: Sociosexuality significantly predicted casual sex engagement after controlling for demographics, OR ¼ 2.06 [1.70, 2.49], p < .001; the interaction with gender was not significant, OR ¼ 1.13 [0.93, 1.36].']
Psychology_124.displayed_text:
Finding A: "Sociosexual orientation is a relatively stable tendency toward or away from casual sex, determined by a combination of heritable factors, sociocultural learning, and past experiences, and reflected in three key components: motivation for, attitudes toward, and past experience with casual sex," the authors write.
Finding B: Sociosexuality significantly predicted casual sex engagement after controlling for demographics, OR ¼ 2.06 [1.70, 2.49], p < .001; the interaction with gender was not significant, OR ¼ 1.13 [0.93, 1.36].

Psychology_tweet_55.News Finding: Neural mechanisms linking depressive symptoms with sleep disturbances (n = 1,017)
Psychology_tweet_55.Paper Finding: We note that the causal relations between sleep and depression is an important topic that deserves much further investigation.
Psychology_tweet_55.News Context: Neural mechanisms linking depressive symptoms with sleep disturbances (n = 1,017)
Psychology_tweet_55.Paper Context: Indeed, we note that poor sleep quality also may have an effect on depression, as shown by the mediation analysis. We note that the causal relations between sleep and depression is an important topic that deserves much further investigation. Although previous studies have found changes in patients with depression in some of the regions of interest identified in this study, including the precuneus and angular gyrus, 43 this is to our knowledge the first study to examine the neural mechanisms underlying the associations of depressive problems with sleep quality and to associate sleep quality with functional connectivity in a large sample of participants.
Psychology_tweet_55.text:
['Finding A: Neural mechanisms linking depressive symptoms with sleep disturbances (n = 1,017)
Finding B: We note that the causal relations between sleep and depression is an important topic that deserves much further investigation.']
Psychology_tweet_55.displayed_text:
Finding A: Neural mechanisms linking depressive symptoms with sleep disturbances (n = 1,017)
Finding B: We note that the causal relations between sleep and depression is an important topic that deserves much further investigation.
